column4: Have you ever reproduced Machine Learning (ML) experiments from the publications of other scientists?

column7:
Relevant details are missing, in most cases related to implementation of specific parts, parameters, etc.
Selection of training and evaluation data unclear, sometimes not publicly available 
Suspicion that optimization has not been done on training data only
No reference implementation available
column9: Not necessarily, since stochastic optimization might find a solution by chance, some preprocessing is not explained, some post-processing to generate the results is hidden

column7: Documentation of experiments incomplete, missing parameter configurations, lack of a clear experimental protocol, e.g., also w.r.t. splits in train and test data
column9: Code often not complete. Some authors just provide code for training and testing their method, but not the whole experimental protocol with train-test-splits, parameter settings, tuning strategies...
column35: the random seed, when randomization is involved in the algorithms
column38: The origin of the data is probably not tracked, whether the data has been pre-processed already
column40: Easy comparison to other methods (reproducibility), would allow for including more competing methods (baselines) if it can be done very easy and fast
column42: But I plan to do so

column7: No resources provided (data they worked with).
column40: It will be easier to reproduce the results.

column7:
- Insufficient description of hyper-parameters that need to be set or tuned appropriately to reproduce the exact results.
- Reproducing training of large neural networks is sometimes not possible due to hardware requirements.
column9: Often, however, neither code nor dataset are provided at all.

column7: Often certain (hyper-)parameters are missing from the paper. Also sometimes researchers use tweaks in their code which are not mentioned in the paper.
column9: Not always. If the experiment uses random values, the seed must also be provided.
column35: Like mentioned above: random seeds, when randomness is used.
column36: I work with C++, Python, R, Tensorflow/Keras, NLTK
column38: I use programming languages, not tools and document the work myself.
column40: This will benefit by being reproducible easier. So you also can find discrepancies between the code and the paper.
column42: I use Anaconda if that counts. When performing experiments I can dump the current library versions used into a file.

column7:
Outdated Code, required packages not mentioned
Hyperparameters not stated in the paper (learning rate (schedule), optimizer, batch size etc.
Paper used batch norm or other regulaization techniques but do not mention them in the paper
No code available at all
column9: If and only if the code is well documented, tested and examples are provided how to use the code to reproduce the work
column36:
Tensorflow
Sacred
Unit test
Format/type checker (pylint, mypy)
column40: It will make them easier to reproduce and also to reuse the existing source code to extend for future research

column7: sometimes parameters or methods are described without enough information

- Incomplete Code
- Code not available
- Missing Hyperparameters
column35: Random numbers used / state of random generators
column40: I do not think that an ERM model of the experiments is that important. It seems like it would be used instead of actual code, or to avoid sharing code.

column7:
- Sometimes the variables exact values are not know
- What kind of preprocessing steps are missing
- Explicit values of the Hyperparams are not mentioned
column9: It is Yes and No question in the same time, if the code is hosted somewhere (open source) then it is strongly yes, but if the code is just explained in terms of Pesudo code then it is no, I always need further details about the experiment
column35:
- Any kind of Hyperparams
- Regularization technique
- Whether they used dropout, with which ratio
column40: If the description is covering all aspects well and this description is open for query, this would be beneficial
